title: China's impact on Thailand
text:
NEWSPAPER SECTION: LIFE | WRITER: KARNJANA KARNJANATAWE - + The total number of Chinese tourists to Thailand during the seven months of this year has surpassed the total of Chinese arrivals in 2014. 
The film crew of Detective Chin Tang at Lao Tak Lak floating market 
However, the number, which has an average of 650,000-700,000 per month, is expected to drop after the bomb blast on Monday evening at the Erawan Shrine, which is at of Bangkok's busiest intersections. The incident killed at least two Chinese visitors, leaving 18 others dead and injuring 125 people as reported on Tuesday morning. 
"My heart felt condolences to the victims, their families and those effected by the incident," said Tourism and Sports Minister Kobkarn Wattanavrangkul. "In this difficult time, the staff of the Ministry of Tourism and Sports and I will work to ensure the safety of our country and citizens." 
The ministry recently revealed that 4.6 million visitors from mainland China visited the Kingdom last year, accounting for 18.6% of the 24.8 million international arrivals in 2014. From January to July this year, Chinese visitors have risen to 4.7 million accounting for 32% of 15 million international arrivals. 
The increasing number of Chinese tourists has prompted the ministry to raise its full-year forecast for Chinese arrivals from 5.4 million announced in the beginning of this year to seven million visitors. 
Although the Chinese government devalued the yuan, the minister believed that this would not impact Thailand. However, Kasikorn Research Centre stated that as China has been an important market for Thailand, the impact of the devaluation on Thailand may be felt in exports and tourism. If the Chinese currency does not fall further, those two sectors should not be more severely threatened. 
Throughout this year, the centre expects Chinese tourist arrivals to reach 7.24 million, increasing 56.1% from last year. However, this projection was announced before Monday's bomb blast. There is no revised number from the Ministry of Tourism and Sports. 
According to Tourism Authority of Thailand (TAT) executive director of East Asia Srisuda Wanapinyosak, TAT believes that Chinese movies shot in Thailand will still attract Chinese tourists to the Kingdom, especially after Detective Chin Tang , or Lost In Thailand Part II , which will be in cinemas later this year. 
The megahit Lost In Thailand is a 2012 Chinese comedy filmed in Chiang Mai, making the northern city one of the top destinations for Chinese travellers. The sequel was shot in Bangkok and Lao Tak Lak, or Pak Khlong Lat Phli Floating Market, in Ratchaburi. Airlines update Qatar Airways has introduced a special in-flight collection for Marvel movie fans. The Marvel Cinematic Universe collection includes Iron Man 1 , 2 and 3 , The Incredible Hulk , Captain America 1 and 2 , Thor , Guardians Of The Galaxy , The Avengers and Avengers: Age Of Ultron . 
The movies are available through its new Oryx One entertainment platform, which is being rolled out across the fleet over the coming months. The Oryx One has the potential to give passengers up to 2,000 entertainment channels, including 60 new blockbuster movies every month, more music and games. Visit www.qatarairways.com . Etihad Airways has officially reopened its refurbished First and Business Class Lounge at Abu Dhabi Airport's Terminal 1. The 1,044m² lounge has seating for 134 passengers with the upgraded armchairs, a dining area, state-of-the-art business amenities, fast Wi-Fi connectivity, USB power outlets, bathrooms with shower facilities and a playroom for children. 
The lounge is open 24 hours and also provides a spa service under the Six Senses brand. Guests can get a complimentary 15-minute spa session in addition to a range of other treatments. Visit www.etihad.com/en-th . Hotels update Best Western International will open Best Western Plus Wanda Grand Hotel on Chaeng Wattana Road by the year-end. The hotel is located close to the city's expressway network, which will be easy for guests to travel to and from Bangkok's two international airports, and across the city, said Best Western managing director of international operations in Asia Olivier Berrivin. 
The hotel provides 183 contemporary rooms and suites. All rooms are equipped with flat-screen TVs with satellite channels, minibars and complimentary Wi-Fi. Other facilities will be eight function rooms, including a 1,014m² banqueting hall, a restaurant, lobby lounge, swimming pool and fitness centre. 
"We expect that this stylish upscale hotel will become a magnet for corporate travellers, due to its proximity to local businesses, government offices and Impact Muang Thong Thani, Thailand's biggest conference and events facility," he said.
